title: 113_s1366
content: The Act is titled the "Verifying Agency Conduct and Needs Through (VACANT) Inspectors General Act" and involves the appointment of an Inspector General. The "Verifying Agency Conduct and Needs Through (VACANT) Inspectors General Act" amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 regarding the appointment of Inspectors General at various establishments. Inspectors General are appointed based on integrity and expertise in accounting, auditing, law, management analysis, public administration, or investigations. Vacancies must be promptly reported to the Council of Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency. The President must appoint an Inspector General for an Office within 210 days of a vacancy declaration. If the President fails to nominate, the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate will appoint based on integrity and expertise, after considering recommendations. The Inspector General Act of 1978 establishes reporting and supervision guidelines for Inspectors General. Each Inspector General reports to the head of the establishment or the next officer in rank, with independence to conduct audits and investigations. Designated Federal Entities are also subject to these provisions. The Inspector General Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.) is amended to specify the appointment process for Inspectors General in designated Federal entities. Inspectors General must be appointed based on integrity and expertise in various fields. Vacancies in the position must be promptly reported to the Council of Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency. Vacancies must be promptly reported to the Council of Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency. If a vacancy is not filled within 210 days, the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate will appoint based on integrity and expertise. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to specify the appointment process for Inspectors General in designated Federal entities. The Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System appoints the Inspector General of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection based on integrity and expertise. The Inspector General Act of 1978 specifies the appointment process for Inspectors General in designated Federal entities. The Act also defines a vacancy in the position of Inspector General as due to death, removal, resignation, or inability to perform duties. The Inspector General Act of 1978 outlines the appointment process for Inspectors General in Federal entities. A vacancy in the position can occur due to death, removal, resignation, or inability to perform duties. Otherwise, the individual must fulfill the functions and duties of the Inspector General position. SEC. 3. AUTHORITY OF INSPECTOR GENERAL. Section 6(e) of the Inspector General Act is amended to specify exceptions for certain Inspector General appointments and their assistants and special agents. The text specifies exceptions for the appointment of Assistant Inspector General for Investigations under an Inspector General. SEC. 4. The Council of Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency must declare all vacancies for Inspector General positions within 30 days of this Act's enactment. The term "vacancy in the position of Inspector General" is defined in the Inspector General Act of 1978. SEC. 5. The Act includes a severability clause. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
